study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of laser-assisted scaling and root planing (including LLLT) compared to SRP alone on reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines in the gingival crevicular fluid of chronic periodontitis patients.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent results regarding the efficacy of LLLT as an adjunct to SRP in reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines, concluding that its role remains unclear and requires further research.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing xerostomia symptoms and increasing salivary flow in head and neck cancer survivors with radiotherapy-induced xerostomia.
results_summary: The study found no evidence or very weak evidence that LLLT can reduce xerostomia symptoms or increase salivary flow in this population. The meta-analysis did not include LLLT studies, and the overall conclusion did not support its use based on current evidence.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer survivors with radiotherapy-induced xerostomia and hyposalivation.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy on tooth movement during canine distalization by evaluating IL-1β and TGF-β1 levels in gingival crevicular fluid.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy accelerated tooth movement by 40% compared to the control group, with no signs of gingival inflammation. The rise in IL-1β levels and its correlation with TGF-β1 levels indicated the tissue effects of laser application.
population_specificity: 15 Angle Class II division I patients aged 12-19 years.
effective_dosage: A gallium-aluminum-arsenide diode laser with an output power of 20 mW, applied as five doses from the buccal and palatal sides on specific days.

study_goal: To determine if low-level laser therapy (LLLT) enhances the efficiency of orthodontic dental alignment compared to fixed appliance treatment alone.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced orthodontic alignment time (211.8 days vs. 284.1 days) and control visits (7 vs. 9.5) compared to the control group, suggesting improved treatment efficiency.
population_specificity: 36 subjects undergoing orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances.
effective_dosage: Diode laser (980 nm, 1 W, continuous wave, total energy density = 150 J/cm²), administered monthly.
study_duration: Treatment duration varied, with alignment completed in 211.8 days (test group) and 284.1 days (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could improve neurometabolic energy levels and cognitive function by transcranially stimulating neuronal mitochondria, potentially preventing or delaying age-related cognitive decline.
results_summary: The study suggests that LLLT may enhance neurometabolic activity, improve cerebral hemodynamics, and support cognitive abilities, offering potential benefits for preventing or delaying dementia-related cognitive impairment. However, many unanswered questions remain regarding its full efficacy and mechanisms.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with or at risk of cognitive impairment, particularly those with vascular risk factors like hypertension, cardiac disease, atherosclerosis, or type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as a nonpharmacologic treatment for chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT is recommended as a nonpharmacologic treatment for chronic low back pain, supported by low-quality evidence, and is part of a broader set of recommended therapies.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain in adult patients with musculoskeletal disorders, particularly assessing adherence to WALT dosage guidelines.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found LLLT significantly reduced pain (pooled mean difference: -0.85) in musculoskeletal disorders, with greater effectiveness when adhering to WALT guidelines (D=-1.52 vs. D=-0.68). High heterogeneity was observed, but subgroup analyses supported clinical relevance.
population_specificity: Adult patients with musculoskeletal disorders (N=1462 across 18 studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence to WALT guidelines noted as enhancing effectiveness).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLT) on pressure ulcers (PU) in humans by systematically reviewing randomized studies.
results_summary: The study found that LLT with a 658 nm wavelength significantly reduced PU area by 71% and improved healing rates, with 47% of ulcers healing completely after one month. No significant effects were observed for other wavelengths or cluster-probe lasers.
population_specificity: Humans with pressure ulcers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (wavelengths used: 904 nm, 940 nm, 808 nm, 658 nm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on wound healing at free gingival graft (FGG) donor sites.
results_summary: LLLT improved wound healing, with higher Complete Wound Epithelization rates, reduced bleeding, better Wound-Healing Index scores, and improved color match compared to the control group. Tissue thickness (TT) was also better preserved in the LLLT group.
population_specificity: Forty patients requiring free gingival grafts.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) combined with photochemotherapy (PCT) compared to LLLT alone for treating chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis in young patients.
results_summary: PCT+LLLT showed a statistically significant reduction in lesion area compared to LLLT alone, with moderate effect size, particularly on Days 6-8. The combination therapy had a greater therapeutic effect in reducing the severity of oral mucositis.
population_specificity: 15 cancer patients aged 3-16 years at Aldenora Bello Hospital in São Luís, Brazil.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy in reducing acute sternotomy pain in patients who underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG).
results_summary: The laser group showed significantly greater pain reduction compared to placebo and control groups, as measured by VAS and McGill Pain Questionnaire, particularly in sensory and affective domains on days 6 and 8 post-surgery.
population_specificity: Ninety volunteers who underwent elective CABG.
effective_dosage: λ of 660 nm and spatial average energy fluency of 1.06 J/cm².
study_duration: Patients were followed for 1 month post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical efficacy of low-level laser therapy in improving peripheral somatosensory neuropathy.
results_summary: Six studies showed that low-level laser therapy reduced sensory impairment and improved the physiological function of sensory nerves. Lasers with wavelengths of 660-860 nm, power of 20-250 mW, and energy density of 0.45-70 J/cm² were effective.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral neuropathy, including those with diabetes, trauma-induced neuropathy, and carpal tunnel syndrome.
effective_dosage: Wavelength range 660-860 nm, radiation power 20-250 mW, energy density 0.45-70 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of LLLT on pain intensity, pain sensitivity, and SF-MPQ indexes in women with myofascial pain, a subtype of TMD.
results_summary: The study compared LLLT and placebo groups in women with myofascial pain, measuring outcomes via VAS, PPT, and SF-MPQ, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 91 women (18-60 years), including 61 with myofascial pain (TMD subtype) and 30 controls.
effective_dosage: 780 nm, 5 J/cm² at pre-established points, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcranial infrared laser stimulation could enhance cognitive performance in two distinct category learning systems mediated by the prefrontal cortex and striatum.
results_summary: The study found that transcranial infrared laser stimulation significantly improved prefrontal rule-based learning compared to placebo, but did not significantly affect reflexive information-integration learning.
population_specificity: 118 participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining Non-ablative Radiofrequency (RF) with Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) improved facial wrinkles compared to RF alone or no treatment.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in nasolabial and periorbital wrinkles between groups, though some aesthetic improvement was noted for nasolabial folds. LLLT did not enhance the effects of RF treatment.
population_specificity: 46 adult women with facial wrinkles.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: 8 weeks of treatment, with an 8-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the efficacy of low-level laser therapy in treating burning mouth syndrome (BMS).
results_summary: Most studies reported low-level laser therapy as effective for managing BMS pain, though methodological variations and lack of statistical analysis due to data heterogeneity limit definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Predominantly post-menopausal women with chronic burning mouth syndrome.
effective_dosage: Laser wavelengths (630-980nm), power output (20-300mW), and irradiation duration (10s-15min) varied across studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) versus a physiotherapeutic and drug protocol (PDP) in treating pain associated with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
results_summary: LLLT showed progressive pain reduction over four weeks, with 0% pain reported by the final week, outperforming PDP in long-term pain control. PDP initially showed higher pain reduction but was less effective over time.
population_specificity: 60 female patients aged 20-50 with TMD, with controlled triggering agents (stress, parafunctional habits).
effective_dosage: 780 nm laser, dose of 35.0 J/cm² (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the analgesic and biochemical effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The active LLLT group showed significant improvements in pain reduction, joint space width, and biochemical markers (CTX-II, MMP-3, 8, and 13) compared to the placebo group after 4 and 8 weeks of treatment. The results suggest LLLT is effective in reducing pain and improving cartilage thickness through biochemical changes.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (n=34, divided into active and placebo groups).
effective_dosage: 1.5 J per point for 60 s at 8 points (total dose of 12 J per session), administered 3 days per week.
study_duration: 4 weeks of treatment, with follow-up at 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for treating diabetic foot ulcers in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study compared LLLT to conventional treatment in 30 patients with grade I diabetic foot ulcers. Results suggested LLLT may improve ulcer healing, but full statistical and clinical outcomes are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 30 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and Meggitt-Wagner grade I foot ulcers of more than 6 weeks duration.
effective_dosage: 660 ± 20 nm, 3 J/cm² (frequency not specified).

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) using a GaAlAs laser (815 nm wavelength) in treating burning mouth syndrome (BMS).
results_summary: The study compared three groups of BMS patients receiving different LLLT treatments, but the abstract does not specify the outcomes or efficacy results.
population_specificity: 44 patients with burning mouth syndrome (BMS).
effective_dosage: Group I received GaAlAs laser (815 nm, 1 W, continuous emissions, 4 s, 4 J, fluence rate 133.3 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as a treatment for androgenetic alopecia among other emerging therapies.
results_summary: The abstract mentions LLLT as one of the treatments for androgenetic alopecia, indicating it is part of the reviewed therapies, but does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes for LLLT alone.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenetic alopecia.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the applicability of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and its clinical protocols for managing various oral disorders, including oral lichen planus, xerostomia, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, herpes labialis, burning mouth syndrome, and oral mucositis.
results_summary: LLLT was found to reduce pain and improve wound healing in conditions like oral mucositis, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, herpes labialis, and oral lichen planus, with minimal adverse effects. It also showed potential in alleviating symptoms of burning mouth syndrome, though evidence for hyposalivation and xerostomia remains inconclusive.
population_specificity: Patients with oral disorders (oral lichen planus, xerostomia, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, herpes labialis, burning mouth syndrome, oral mucositis).
effective_dosage: Not Assessed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could accelerate orthodontic tooth movement in patients with crowded maxillary incisors.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced the overall treatment time and improved the leveling and alignment percentage at early stages (T1 and T2) compared to the control group. The results were statistically significant, indicating LLLT's effectiveness in accelerating orthodontic tooth movement.
population_specificity: 26 patients with severe to extreme maxillary incisors irregularity requiring premolar extraction.
effective_dosage: 2 J/point applied at four points per tooth (two buccal, two palatal), repeated on days 3, 7, 14, and then every 15 days starting from the second month until the end of the leveling and alignment stage.
study_duration: Until the end of the leveling and alignment stage (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to nonsurgical periodontal treatment improves clinical outcomes in type 2 diabetes mellitus patients with chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: Test sites treated with SRP + LLLT showed significant improvement in plaque index (PI) and bleeding on probing (BOP) in deep pockets at the 1-month follow-up, but no differences were observed in other periodontal parameters compared to control sites. The study concluded that LLLT provided minimal short-term additional benefit for deep pocket healing in these patients.
population_specificity: 22 chronic periodontitis patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: 808 nm GaAlAs diode laser at 4.46 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on inflammatory response, wound healing, and pain reduction after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: LLLT reduced wound temperature and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), improved wound healing, and decreased pain compared to the placebo group. The therapy also controlled the inflammatory process and reduced seroma formation.
population_specificity: 85 patients who underwent Roux en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) via open surgery.
effective_dosage: CW diode laser applied at 10 different points on the surgical scar in three sessions.
study_duration: Three sessions of laser application (exact duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on LLLT for neuropathic pain to establish a "therapeutic window" for effective treatment parameters.
results_summary: Experimental studies showed better results with LLLT at infrared laser powers above 70mW, while clinical studies were inconclusive on parameters but demonstrated LLLT's effectiveness. Further high-rigor studies are needed to optimize protocols.
population_specificity: Experimental animals (10 studies) and humans (4 studies).
effective_dosage: Infrared laser powers above 70mW (specific dosage and frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the healing effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on sternotomy incisions in patients who underwent coronary artery bypass graft (CABG).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study design includes a randomized controlled trial with placebo and control groups to evaluate LLLT's effects.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent CABG with longitudinal sternotomy incisions.
effective_dosage: λ = 660 nm and spatial average energy fluency (SAEF) = 1.06 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether applying low-level laser therapy (LLLT) before or after plyometric exercise reduces markers of quadriceps muscle damage and if timing (pre- or post-exercise) affects outcomes.
results_summary: LLLT applied before or after plyometric exercise significantly reduced muscle echo intensity compared to placebo, with a trend toward reduced muscle soreness, but no significant effect on strength impairment was observed.
population_specificity: 24 healthy men divided into pre-exercise and post-exercise treatment groups.
effective_dosage: 810 nm, 200 mW per diode, 6 J per diode, 240 J per leg.
study_duration: Assessments were made at baseline, 24, 48, and 72 hours post-exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could reduce fatigue and improve neuromuscular performance in the ankle plantar flexors of healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced the dynamometric fatigue index compared to control and placebo groups, though median frequency changes during fatigue were similar across all groups. The results suggest LLLT may help mitigate fatigue in healthy individuals when applied prior to exercise.
population_specificity: 60 young, physically active volunteers of both genders.
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the medium-term effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on postexercise skeletal muscle recovery and performance enhancement, and to identify the optimal dose of 810 nm LLLT.
results_summary: LLLT at 50 J significantly increased maximum voluntary contraction (MVC) and improved biochemical markers (CK and IL-6) related to muscle damage and inflammation, while 10 J also showed benefits but with lesser efficacy. However, LLLT had no effect on delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS), and the 30 J dose showed no significant effects.
population_specificity: 28 high-level soccer athletes
effective_dosage: 10, 30, or 50 J per site (six sites of quadriceps)
study_duration: Single pre-exercise application, with follow-up assessments up to 96 hours post-exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing the relapse of orthodontically rotated teeth by reviewing available studies.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT's effect on relapse of corrected tooth rotations depends on energy density—low energy density may promote relapse, while high energy density might alleviate it. However, the available investigations were limited, highlighting the need for more well-designed human trials.
population_specificity: Animal experiments and one human study (specific population not detailed).
effective_dosage: Energy density (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the healing effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and LED therapy on sternotomy wound healing after CABG surgery.
results_summary: LLLT and LED groups showed similarly reduced hyperemia and incision bleeding or dehiscence compared to control, with no significant differences between hyperglycemic and normoglycemic patients. Both coherent (laser) and non-coherent (LED) light were effective in promoting sternotomy healing by the eighth day postsurgery.
population_specificity: 120 volunteers who underwent elective CABG surgery.
effective_dosage: Laser (λ640 nm, SAEF 1.06 J/cm²) and LED (λ620 nm, 6 J/cm²).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed by the eighth day postsurgery.

study_goal: To consolidate evidence on Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for hair growth and identify gaps for its widespread acceptance in treating hair loss.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT shows promise for hair growth but lacks standardized protocols, visual evidence, and long-term data. Comparisons with traditional therapies were difficult due to variations in study design and efficacy measurements.
population_specificity: Men and women with androgenetic alopecia.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing postoperative pain and edema after secondary palatal operations in children.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced postoperative pain and edema compared to the control group, with lower pain scores and fewer analgesic doses needed. The effects were statistically significant from the first to the sixth postoperative day for pain and from the second to the seventh day for edema.
population_specificity: 20 children (aged ~5-6 years) undergoing secondary palatal operations.
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.
study_duration: Intervention was administered immediately after surgery, with follow-up assessments up to the 7th postoperative day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to non-surgical treatment of chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: The study measured periodontal parameters (PPD, GI, PI, CAL, BOP) and analyzed GCF samples at various intervals, suggesting LLLT may have adjunctive benefits in periodontal treatment, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Systemically healthy, non-smoking adults with chronic periodontitis and bilateral premolar teeth with probing pocket depth of 5-7 mm.
effective_dosage: Energy density of 7.64 J/cm² (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at baseline, first, third, and sixth months after treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in treating mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) through a meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT improved hand grip strength, reduced pain (measured by VAS), and enhanced sensory nerve action potential (SNAP) at 12 weeks compared to controls, though one study heavily influenced these results. No significant differences were observed in other parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (270 wrists in the LLLT group, 261 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence for Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in accelerating tooth movement, preventing orthodontic relapse, and modulating acute pain during fixed appliance treatment in children and young adults.
results_summary: The study found promising results for LLLT in accelerating tooth movement and reducing acute pain, but the quality of evidence was very low for tooth movement and low for pain modulation. No studies met the criteria for evaluating relapse prevention.
population_specificity: Children and young adults undergoing fixed orthodontic appliance treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of ultrasonic periodontal debridement (UPD) alone versus UPD combined with antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) for treating chronic periodontitis in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found that while both UPD alone and UPD combined with aPDT significantly reduced probing depth, there were no statistically significant differences between the two treatments. The adjunct aPDT did not provide additional benefits over UPD alone.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients with moderate to severe generalized chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two different laser therapy regimens (850 nm Ga-Al-As vs. combined 650 nm He-Ne, 785 nm, and 980 nm Ga-Al-As) on pain, lumbar range of motion, and functional capacity in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: Both laser therapy regimens showed statistically significant improvements in pain severity, range of motion, and functional disability. The combined plaque laser therapy (group 2) demonstrated superior improvements in lateral flexion measurements and disability scores compared to the single-wavelength laser (group 1), though no significant difference was found in pain severity.
population_specificity: 49 patients with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions of laser therapy (specific power/dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (15 sessions implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) influences orthodontic treatment with invisible removal aligners, specifically its ability to enhance tooth movement and reduce required aligner wear time.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT combined with aligners achieved the same tooth movement in 12 hours of daily wear as traditional 22-hour wear, with the laser group completing treatment successfully while the control group did not. LLLT made the treatment more comfortable by reducing required aligner wear time.
population_specificity: 21 subjects undergoing orthodontic treatment with invisible removal aligners, divided into a laser group (10 patients) and a control group (11 patients).
effective_dosage: Laser external bio-stimulation was given every second week (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Treatment duration was not explicitly stated, but aligners were worn for 2 weeks each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine neural inhibition as a mechanism underlying pain relief and anesthetic effects of photobiomodulation (PBM).
results_summary: Evidence indicates PBM inhibits nerve function in various models, including nociceptor-specific inhibition and local conduction block, leading to reduced pain transmission. PBM-induced changes are reversible with no side effects or nerve damage.
population_specificity: Humans, animal models, and cell cultures.
effective_dosage: Not Assessed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single-session of LLLT with a 940 nm diode laser applied immediately after impacted tooth extraction could reduce postoperative pain, swelling, and trismus.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in pain, swelling, or trismus between the laser-treated and placebo sides, though clinical outcomes suggested less swelling and trismus on the laser-treated side.
population_specificity: Thirty-five outpatients with similarly impacted lower third molars on both sides.
effective_dosage: 4 J/cm² in a single session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces pain and improves perineal healing after episiotomy in postpartum women.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in perineal healing between the LLLT and placebo groups. Perineal pain scores were higher in the LLLT group initially and after the third session, but no difference was observed 7-10 days postpartum.
population_specificity: 54 postpartum women who had a spontaneous birth with a right mediolateral episiotomy.
effective_dosage: Three sessions of LLLT (or sham) at 6-10 hours, 20-24 hours, and 40-48 hours after the first session.
study_duration: Approximately 48 hours (three sessions within two days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could reduce the incidence of Postherpetic Neuralgia (PHN) when administered during different phases of herpes zoster eruption.
results_summary: LLLT administered within the first 5 days of herpes zoster eruption significantly reduced PHN incidence at 1, 3, and 6 months compared to the control group. The subacute group (days 6-14) showed reduced PHN incidence only at 3 months.
population_specificity: Patients with herpes zoster, divided into acute (first 5 days), subacute (days 6-14), and control (no LLLT) groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Acute group: first 5 days; subacute group: days 6-14.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) as an adjuvant to conventional periodontal treatment in Down syndrome patients with periodontal disease.
results_summary: Both conventional scaling and root planing (SRP) and SRP combined with aPDT improved periodontal conditions, with no significant difference in probing pocket depth reduction between the two treatments. Both treatments showed significant clinical improvement.
population_specificity: 13 Down syndrome patients aged 18 or older with at least one tooth per quadrant exhibiting probing pocket depth ≥5 mm.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal timing (before or after training sessions) for applying phototherapy irradiation in association with strength training to enhance performance.
results_summary: Volunteers treated with phototherapy before and placebo after training sessions showed significant improvements in peak torque (MVC) and load (1-RM) tests compared to other groups, with no reported side effects or thermal tissue damage. The study concluded that phototherapy before exercise enhances strength gains.
population_specificity: 48 male volunteers aged 18-35 years.
effective_dosage: Cluster probes with four laser diodes of 905 nm, four LEDs of 875 nm, and four LEDs of 640 nm (manufactured by Multi Radiance Medical™).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether photobiomodulation via Low-Level Laser Therapy could stimulate mitochondrial energy production in nerve cells to improve cerebral perfusion and potentially prevent cognitive decline.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that photobiomodulation, alongside novel pharmacological agents, may become an important tool in treating or preventing cognitive decline by enhancing cerebral perfusion and mitochondrial energy production. However, specific efficacy data for Low-Level Laser Therapy alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals at risk of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) due to cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy in treating nipple pain caused by breastfeeding-related lesions.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in pain intensity (2.0 cm decrease on a visual analogue scale) 24 hours after the first laser session and maintained lower pain levels compared to the control group. Low-level laser therapy was deemed effective for pain relief and prolonging exclusive breastfeeding.
population_specificity: Fifty-nine breastfeeding women with nipple lesions admitted to a university-affiliated hospital in São Paulo, Brazil.
effective_dosage: InGaAIP laser, 660 nm, 40 mW, 5 J/cm² energy density for 5 seconds per session (total energy = 0.6 Joules), administered at 0, 24, and 48 hours after diagnosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two different power densities of photobiomodulation (PBM) on wound healing and postoperative comfort in the donor palatine area after connective tissue graft removal.
results_summary: The study found that PBM at 60 J/cm² resulted in statistically significant smaller wounds at day 7 compared to 30 J/cm² and sham treatment. All patients reported mild discomfort, with low analgesic use, and no scarring was observed.
population_specificity: 51 patients with buccal gingival recession.
effective_dosage: 60 J/cm² and 30 J/cm², applied postoperatively.
study_duration: Evaluated at baseline and 7, 14, 45, 60, and 90 days after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on spastic muscles in post-stroke patients with spasticity, focusing on pain reduction, muscle fatigue onset, and torque peak.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain intensity, increased time to onset of muscle fatigue, and improved torque peak, but did not significantly affect the root mean square (RMS) value of muscle electrical activity.
population_specificity: 15 post-stroke patients (average age 51.5 ± 11.8 years) with spasticity, 11-48 months post-stroke onset.
effective_dosage: Diode laser, 100 mW, 808 nm, beam spot area 0.0314 cm², 127.39 J/cm² per point, 40 seconds per application.
study_duration: Three consecutive phases (control, placebo, and real LLLT), duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of transdermal low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on endothelial function in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: LLLT increased glutathione (GSH) levels and decreased angiostatin concentration, indicating enhanced antioxidant and angiogenic potential. No significant changes were observed in VEGF, FGF, SDMA, ADMA, or nitric oxide pathway metabolites.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (n=40, age 20-40 years).
effective_dosage: 808 nm laser, 50 mW, 1.6 W/cm² energy density, 20 J/day (total 60 J over 3 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of physical therapy modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, on pain, function, and range of motion in individuals with subacromial pain syndrome (SAPS).
results_summary: The study found high-level evidence that Low-Level Laser Therapy lacks beneficial effects on pain, function, or range of motion in SAPS treatment. It should not be recommended based on the synthesized evidence.
population_specificity: Individuals with subacromial pain syndrome (SAPS).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pre-exercise low-level phototherapy (LEDtherapy or LASERtherapy) in improving exercise capacity and muscle performance compared to placebo.
results_summary: LASERtherapy showed statistically significant improvements in exercise capacity (increased repetitions, delayed exhaustion, reduced lactate levels) and muscle performance (increased peak torque). LEDtherapy showed no significant differences in power, lactate levels, or time to exhaustion.
population_specificity: 297 participants in randomized controlled trials and crossover studies.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of electrotherapy modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for treating rotator cuff disease.
results_summary: LLLT showed short-term benefits over placebo in people with rotator cuff disease, but combining it with other physical therapy interventions provided few additional benefits. No adverse events were reported for LLLT.
population_specificity: Adults with rotator cuff disease (e.g., subacromial impingement syndrome, rotator cuff tendinitis, calcific tendinitis).
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Up to three weeks (for placebo-controlled trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two different phototherapy cluster probes (small vs. large) on reducing elbow flexor muscle fatigue.
results_summary: Both large and small cluster probes significantly increased time to exhaustion (14-15%) compared to placebo, with no difference between the two probes. No significant differences were observed in maximal strength decrement or EMG signals between active and placebo treatments.
population_specificity: 10 physically active males aged 18-35 years.
effective_dosage: 60 J per muscle (LC: 33 diodes, SC: 9 diodes).
study_duration: Single session per treatment, with sessions separated by at least 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of combining Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with strength training on muscle performance in elderly women.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT combined with strength training improved muscle performance, including increased work, peak torque, power, and 1-RM load, while reducing lactate concentration post-exercise. No differences were observed in the 6-MWT or fatigue levels among groups.
population_specificity: Elderly women (48 participants meeting inclusion criteria).
effective_dosage: 808 nm, 100 mW, 7 J (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could reduce chemotherapy-related oral mucositis grading and pain in children undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain in children with chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis but did not significantly reduce the grading of oral mucositis compared to sham therapy.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-18 years undergoing cancer therapy with oral mucositis grade 2 or higher.
effective_dosage: 830 nm wavelength, 150 mW power, 1 cm² spot size, 30 s per cm², energy density 4.5 J/cm², administered for 4 consecutive days.
study_duration: 4 days (from diagnosis day plus 3 consecutive days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of combining PDT and LLLT with conventional SRP in treating chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that combining PDT and LLLT with SRP (Group III) resulted in significantly greater improvements in clinical parameters (probing depth and clinical attachment level) compared to SRP alone or SRP with PDT after 6 months.
population_specificity: 24 patients (15 males, 9 females) with untreated chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (LLLT parameters not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: 6 months (follow-up measurements at baseline, 1, 3, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on functional capacity, perceived exertion, and blood lactate levels in hospitalized patients with heart failure.
results_summary: Both active and placebo LLLT groups showed increased 6-minute walk test distance compared to baseline, but no intergroup difference was observed. Active LLLT significantly reduced perceived exertion and favorably modulated blood lactate metabolism compared to placebo, though it did not improve functional capacity.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with systolic heart failure (left ventricular ejection fraction <45%).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) compared to a sham device for treating female pattern hair loss (FPHL).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in participant-reported effectiveness between LLLT and sham devices, but noted an increase in hair count from baseline with LLLT. Adverse events were not reported per treatment arm, limiting safety conclusions.
population_specificity: Women with female pattern hair loss (FPHL).
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in repairing the mid palatal suture after rapid maxillary expansion (RME) in children.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT-treated patients showed greater approximation in the anterior and posterior superior suture areas compared to the placebo group, suggesting LLLT stimulates suture repair during the retention phase after RME.
population_specificity: 39 children aged 6-12 years who underwent RME.
effective_dosage: 660 nm, 100 mW, CW, InGaAlP laser, 332 mW/cm², 60 s to four points along the suture and 30 s to a point each side, applied seven times on days 1, 7, 14, 28, 42, 56, and 70.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cognitive effects of transcranial infrared laser stimulation (LLLT), acute aerobic exercise, and their combination on sustained attention and working memory tasks.
results_summary: Both LLLT and acute aerobic exercise significantly improved reaction time in the psychomotor vigilance task (PVT) and increased correct responses in the delayed match-to-sample task (DMS), demonstrating cognitive enhancement. The combined treatment (LLLT + EX) showed similar effects but no significantly greater improvement than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: 60 healthy young adults
effective_dosage: 1064 nm continuous wave, 250 mW/cm², 60 J/cm² per site (13.6 cm²), total 8 min
study_duration: Single session (8 min for LLLT, 20 min for EX)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), including laser acupuncture, has specific benefits for chronic non-specific low back pain (CNLBP).
results_summary: The study found significant short-term pain reduction and global improvement in CNLBP with LLLT, particularly at doses ≥3 J per point, in participants with baseline pain <30 months, and in non-acupuncture LLLT trials. The benefit was supported by moderate-quality evidence (GRADE).
population_specificity: Adults with chronic non-specific low back pain (CNLBP).
effective_dosage: At least 3 Joules (J) per point.
study_duration: Up to short-term follow-up (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) is an effective treatment for androgenetic alopecia (AGA) based on objective measurements and patient satisfaction.
results_summary: Nine out of 11 studies showed statistically significant improvements in hair count/density, while two out of four studies reported significant improvements in hair thickness and tensile strength. Patient satisfaction was positive but less pronounced than objective outcomes.
population_specificity: 680 patients (444 males, 236 females) with androgenetic alopecia.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and analgesic efficacy of superpulsed low-level laser therapy (SLLLT) following bilateral extraction of impacted mandibular third molars.
results_summary: The study found that SLLLT significantly reduced pain and swelling in the treated site compared to the control site within the first 5 days post-surgery, with no reported side effects and good patient tolerance. It also suggested a potential reduction in postoperative drug intake.
population_specificity: 25 patients undergoing bilateral extraction of impacted mandibular third molars in a single surgery.
effective_dosage: GaAs laser diode applied at T0, 24 hours, and 48 hours post-surgery (specific energy parameters not detailed).
study_duration: Treatment administered over 48 hours, with follow-up at 7 and 14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on reducing postoperative complications like airway obstruction and obstructive sleep apnoea in children undergoing superiorly based pharyngeal flap surgery.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved oxygen saturation and reduced the incidence of obstructive sleep apnoea and steroid need in the first three postoperative days compared to the control group. Edema reduction was also more pronounced in the LLLT group on days 2 and 3.
population_specificity: 30 children undergoing superiorly based pharyngeal flap surgery, divided into two groups of 15 each.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: First postoperative days (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining low-level laser therapy (LLLT) with oral motor exercises (OM-exercises) was more effective than LLLT alone or other therapies in rehabilitating patients with chronic temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: The study found that combining LLLT with OM-exercises (GI) was more effective in promoting TMD rehabilitation than LLLT alone (GIV). All treated groups showed significant improvement in outcome measures, with stability at follow-up, but GIV did not improve orofacial functions. Similar results were observed with orofacial myofunctional therapy (OMT).
population_specificity: 82 patients with chronic TMD and 20 healthy subjects (control group).
effective_dosage: AsGaAl laser; 780-nm wavelength; average power of 60 mW, 40 s, and 60 ± 1.0 J/cm².
study_duration: Evaluations at baseline (T1), immediately after treatment (T2), and at follow-up (T3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy as a treatment option for steroid-refractory oral lichen planus.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that some results from studies on Low-Level Laser Therapy were promising, but further rigorous trials are needed to confirm long-term efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: Patients with steroid-refractory oral lichen planus.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and LEDs in reducing pain in hyperglycemic and normoglycemic patients after coronary artery bypass surgery.
results_summary: LLLT and LED groups showed significantly greater pain reduction compared to placebo and control groups, with similar effects in both hyperglycemic and normoglycemic patients. Pain relief was observed by the 6th and 8th postoperative day, and nearly all patients reported no pain after one month.
population_specificity: 120 volunteers who underwent elective coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery, divided into hyperglycemic and normoglycemic subgroups.
effective_dosage: LLLT (λ = 640 nm, SAEF = 1.06 J/cm²); LED (λ = 660 ± 20 nm, SAEF = 0.24 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could enhance bone regeneration at the midpalatal suture following rapid maxillary expansion in patients with transverse maxillary deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly improved bone regeneration at the midpalatal suture compared to the control group, as evidenced by higher optical density values in the laser-treated group after 4 months. The difference was statistically significant (p=0.05), indicating LLLT accelerated the repair process.
population_specificity: 8-14-year-old patients with transverse maxillary deficiency.
effective_dosage: 12 LLLT sessions (GaAlAs, p=70 mW, λ=780 nm, Ø=0.04 cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on reducing pain and swelling after the surgical removal of impacted third molars.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain levels at all time points and decreased swelling on days 2, 4, and 7 post-surgery compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Patients with symmetrically impacted mandibular third molars.
effective_dosage: Intraoral application of a 660-nm laser (200 mW, 6 J per point at 4 points) followed by extraoral application of an 810-nm laser (200 mW, 6 J per point at 3 points), with 810-nm irradiation repeated on days 2 and 4.

study_goal: To determine the immediate pain relief effect of low-level laser therapy on sports injuries in athletes and the degree of pain relief provided by the therapy.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy was effective in 75% of the laser group, significantly reducing pain by 28.74% compared to the placebo group, which showed no significant effect. The difference in pain relief rate between the groups was statistically significant (p<0.001).
population_specificity: 32 college athletes with motion pain at a defined site.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and botulinum toxin in reducing myofascial pain and improving mouth opening in patients with temporomandibular disorder.
results_summary: Both LLLT and botulinum toxin effectively reduced pain, with LLLT showing faster results (significant reduction by day 12 vs. day 30 for toxin). Neither treatment significantly improved mouth opening.
population_specificity: 15 patients with temporomandibular disorder seeking care at a dental clinic.
effective_dosage: GaAlAs laser, 100mW power, 830nm wavelength, continuous light emission.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but assessments were made up to day 30.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct treatment for bisphosphonate or denosumab-associated osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ).
results_summary: LLLT showed an overall response rate of 55%, outperforming controls (30%), with anti-inflammatory, pain-relieving, and wound-healing effects. The therapy was easy to administer and had no reported side effects, though further research is needed to confirm its safety regarding carcinogenic processes.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with bisphosphonate or denosumab-associated osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether low-level laser therapy has positive effects on the treatment of bisphosphonate-related osteonecrosis of the jaw.
results_summary: The study found that treatment modalities including laser were associated with superior outcomes in terms of cure or improvement of lesions compared to conventional surgical or drug therapy. Combined treatment with antibiotics, minimally invasive surgery, and low-level laser therapy in early disease stages was recommended as the gold standard.
population_specificity: Patients with bisphosphonate-related osteonecrosis of the jaw.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as part of multimodal care for managing grades I-II neck pain and associated disorders (NAD) lasting more than 3 months.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT may be considered for NAD grades I-II >3 months duration when combined with structured patient education, but it was not recommended for NAD grade III ≤3 months due to evidence of no effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults with grades I-III neck pain and associated disorders (NAD) of less than 6 months duration.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy in accelerating orthodontic tooth movement, specifically focusing on pain reduction and movement speed.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that low-level laser therapy accelerates induced tooth movement, though some statistically significant differences were noted in specific timeframes (three months for the maxilla, one month for the mandible). Most articles reviewed were of high quality, but only a few showed significant effects.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment with first premolar extractions.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Varied by study (up to three months for maxilla, one month for mandible)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces postoperative pain in children following primary molar extraction.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in pain scores between the LLLT and control groups, though the control group had higher mean pain scores initially. Analgesic use was higher in the control group on the first evening but equal on subsequent days.
population_specificity: Children requiring bilateral extraction of primary molars (n=37).
effective_dosage: GaAlAs diode laser (810 nm, continuous mode, 0.3 W, 180 sec, 4 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the role of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in cardiac remodeling after myocardial infarction.
results_summary: The review found mixed results, with three studies showing no effect of LLLT on infarct size and only one study reporting positive effects on cardiac performance. The cardioprotective role of LLLT was linked to anti-inflammatory, pro-angiogenic, and anti-oxidant mechanisms.
population_specificity: Studies with a well-standardized coronary occlusion model in vivo (animal or human not specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) provides additional benefits compared to scaling and root planing (SRP) alone in non-surgical periodontal treatment.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant short-term benefits in improving probing pocket depth and interleukin-1β levels at 1 and 2 months but failed to demonstrate significant intermediate-term (3-6 months) effects on clinical parameters or alveolar bone density. The long-term effects remain unclear due to methodological weaknesses and insufficient studies.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontal disease
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Short-term (1-2 months) and intermediate-term (3-6 months) follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could reduce tooth sensitivity induced by in-office bleaching and compare the effectiveness of red vs. infrared lasers.
results_summary: LLLT with an infrared diode laser significantly reduced tooth sensitivity at 24 hours post-bleaching compared to red laser and placebo, though both laser types showed comparable efficacy by 48 hours. No significant difference in tooth whitening efficacy was observed among groups.
population_specificity: 66 patients undergoing in-office tooth bleaching with 40% hydrogen peroxide.
effective_dosage: Red laser (660 nm, 200 mW, 15 s, 12 J/cm²); infrared laser (810 nm, similar parameters).
study_duration: Single session (15 seconds per laser application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) versus clonazepam in treating burning mouth syndrome (BMS) patients.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant reductions in pain sensation across multiple parameters (VAS, McGill Pain Questionnaire, PPI, OHIP-49) at 12 weeks post-treatment, outperforming clonazepam. Anxiety and depression levels remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: 33 BMS patients (25 female, 8 male, mean age 67.12).
effective_dosage: 300 mW, 980-nm AlGaAs diode laser, Fluence of 10 J/cm², two sessions weekly for 5 weeks.
study_duration: 5 weeks for LLLT, 21 days for clonazepam.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of 5 days of 810-nm low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on inflammatory markers, muscle damage, and performance in young water polo players.
results_summary: LLLT showed a moderate improvement in the 30-second crossbar jump test (8.7% increase) but no significant change in 200-m swimming performance. It reduced creatine kinase levels but had mixed effects on inflammatory markers, with no significant differences between LLLT and placebo groups for most outcomes.
population_specificity: Twenty young male water polo players.
effective_dosage: Not specified (delivered to eight points on the adductor muscle region after each training day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy on neuromuscular parameters and health status in elderly women with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Laser therapy improved health status and electrical activity but had no effect on muscle mass. Combined with electrical stimulation, it enhanced muscle thickness and cross-sectional area.
population_specificity: Elderly women with knee osteoarthritis (n=45).
effective_dosage: 4-6 J per point, 6 points at the knee joint.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the treatment effects of 5% amlexanox and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain relief and ulcer size reduction in patients with minor aphthous stomatitis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief between LLLT and amlexanox on the first and seventh days of treatment. Both treatments significantly reduced ulcer sizes and pain scores.
population_specificity: 50 participants with minor aphthous ulcers.
effective_dosage: Not specified for LLLT (only mentioned as a treatment modality).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological basis of Low-Level Laser Therapy's effectiveness in preventing oral mucositis in head and neck cancer patients undergoing chemoradiation and to assess potential tumor-related risks.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT is effective in reducing oral mucositis but identified multiple LLLT-activated pathways linked to negative tumor outcomes, prompting a need for further investigation to ensure its safety in cancer patients.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing chemoradiation for head and neck cancers.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) at two different fluences (12.5 J/cm² and 25 J/cm²) on third-degree burns in rats, focusing on inflammatory response and tissue repair.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT at 25 J/cm² reduced inflammatory infiltrate and COX-2 expression while increasing VEGF immunomarking, suggesting enhanced tissue repair and angiogenesis compared to 12.5 J/cm² and the control group.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced third-degree burns.
effective_dosage: 12.5 J/cm² and 25 J/cm² per point of application, applied immediately and on days 2, 4, 6, and 8 post-injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the longitudinal effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain, swelling, and reduced joint mobility in patients with Bouchard's and Heberden's osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain and swelling and increased range of motion after five and seven treatments, with large effect sizes. The benefits persisted for 8 weeks after treatment, with no further improvement beyond seven sessions.
population_specificity: 34 patients (32 females, mean age 61.21 years) with Bouchard's and Heberden's OA.
effective_dosage: 5-10 LLLT sessions administered twice a week.
study_duration: Varied by group (5, 7, or 10 sessions), with follow-up assessments up to 8 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if low-level laser therapy (LLLT) applied to the PC 6 acupuncture points could reduce the gag reflex in children undergoing maxillary radiography.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced gagging severity compared to the control group, with statistically significant differences (P = .000). No significant correlation was found between gagging severity and anxiety scores.
population_specificity: 25 children with moderate-to-very severe gag reflexes requiring maxillary molar radiography.
effective_dosage: 300 mW, energy density 4 J/cm², applied for 14 seconds per wrist.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on the osseointegration of titanium dental implants and evaluate the methodological quality of existing studies.
results_summary: Animal studies showed a positive effect of LLLT on osseointegration, but methodological biases were noted. Only two human studies were conducted, and the lack of a standardized protocol limits conclusive meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Primarily animals (high risk of bias), with two studies in human bone under different conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (multiple protocols and laser types used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of combined low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and passive stretching versus placebo LLLT with the same stretching exercises in patients with Ankylosing spondylitis.
results_summary: Group A (LLLT + stretching) showed significant pain and function improvement after 8 weeks, with pain relief persisting at follow-up. Group B (placebo + stretching) did not achieve statistically significant functional improvements beyond pain relief.
population_specificity: 48 patients with Ankylosing spondylitis.
effective_dosage: λ = 820 nm Ga-Al-As laser, 60 mW/cm², 4.5 J per point, 27.0 J total per session, twice weekly (weeks 1-4), once weekly (weeks 5-8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy on tissue repair in diabetic foot ulcers.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in wound size compared to the control group (p<0.05) and reported intense pain improvement in the treated group.
population_specificity: Sixteen type II diabetic patients with lower limb ulcers.
effective_dosage: 632.8 nm wavelength, 30 mW peak power, 4J/cm², 80 seconds per application, 12 sessions (3 weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence on the effectiveness of passive physical modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for managing whiplash-associated disorders (WAD) and neck pain and associated disorders (NAD).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT did not offer benefits for persistent NAD grades I-II or recent NAD grades III, suggesting it is ineffective for managing neck pain in these populations.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent NAD grades I-II and recent NAD grades III.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how transcranial laser stimulation affects cerebral hemodynamics and oxygenation in the human brain.
results_summary: The study found that transcranial laser stimulation increased oxygenated hemoglobin and decreased deoxygenated hemoglobin, improving cerebral oxygenation in a dose-dependent manner, with effects persisting post-stimulation.
population_specificity: Nine healthy male and female participants aged 18-40.
effective_dosage: 3.4 W over 13.6 cm² (0.25 W/cm² irradiance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and biochemical effectiveness of guided tissue regeneration (GTR) alone versus GTR combined with low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating furcation II periodontal defects over 6 months.
results_summary: Both GTR and GTR plus LLLT improved periodontal parameters (PPD, CAL, HPD) and increased ALP and OC levels in GCF. At 6 months, the LLLT group showed significantly greater improvements in PPD, CAL, HPD, and ALP compared to GTR alone.
population_specificity: Patients with furcation II periodontal defects (33 defects included in the study).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain, swelling, and trismus following surgical extraction of third molars.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain, swelling, and trismus at 48 hours and 7 days postoperatively compared to the control group. A single dose of LLLT was effective in alleviating postoperative discomfort associated with third molar extraction.
population_specificity: 22 patients undergoing surgical extraction of mandibular third molars with similar radiographic positions.
effective_dosage: LLLT was applied at 10 points (4 intraoral near the socket and 6 extraoral along the masseter muscle).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy on bone remodeling and tooth movement acceleration in orthodontics.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy reduced post-adjustment pain, but results on tooth movement acceleration were mixed—low dosage increased movement while high dosage had inhibitory effects. Future studies are needed to establish optimal protocols.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied orthodontic patients).
effective_dosage: Low and high dosages mentioned (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for relieving pain in patients with nonspecific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP) through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain scores compared to placebo, but no significant effects were observed for disability scores or spinal range of motion. The results suggest LLLT is effective for pain relief in NSCLBP but lacks evidence for functional improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with nonspecific chronic low back pain (NSCLBP).
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review noninvasive modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for skin tightening across various anatomical sites.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Low-Level Laser Therapy, focusing instead on a broader review of multiple modalities.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of noninvasive treatments for skin tightening).
effective_dosage: Not mentioned

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of low-level phototherapy (LED or LASER therapy) on pain, skeletal muscle injury, and muscle function in individuals undergoing an exercise protocol.
results_summary: The study found that LASER therapy applied before exercise reduced CK levels, but no significant effects were observed for edema, range of movement, or strength. The evidence suggests low-level phototherapy may not substantially impact exercise-induced muscle injury or pain.
population_specificity: People undergoing an exercise protocol (317 participants across 15 studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Single treatment session (before or after exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in preventing oral mucositis in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients undergoing chemoradiation.
results_summary: LLLT reduced morbidity and was more cost-effective than placebo, with lower costs for opioid use, gastrostomy feeding, and hospitalization, though laser therapy itself was more expensive. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio was US$ 4961.37 per grade 3-4 oral mucositis case prevented.
population_specificity: 94 patients with HNSCC of nasopharynx, oropharynx, and hypopharynx receiving chemoradiation.
effective_dosage: InGaAlP laser diode (660 nm, 100 mW, 4J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could reduce healing time between extraction/socket graft and implant placement by evaluating histological changes in grafted sockets.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT-treated sockets showed abundant new bone formation within 60 days, compared to 120 days in the control group, suggesting LLLT accelerates healing. No inflammation was noted in the LLLT group.
population_specificity: 30 patients undergoing socket grafting with a particulate allograft material.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining scaling and root planing (SRP) with low-level laser therapy (LLLT) improves carotid hemodynamics more effectively than SRP alone in patients with periodontal disease.
results_summary: SRP + LLLT significantly improved periodontal indices (e.g., gingival index) more than SRP alone and increased common carotid wall shear stress by 11% after 5 months, suggesting cardiovascular benefits. No significant changes were observed in other hemodynamic parameters.
population_specificity: 40 patients with periodontal disease (20 treated with SRP, 20 with SRP + LLLT).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current research and international consensus on the diagnosis and management of osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ), including the potential role of Low-Level Laser Therapy as an experimental treatment.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Low-Level Laser Therapy as one of several experimental therapies being evaluated for ONJ, but no specific results or outcomes related to its efficacy are provided.
population_specificity: Oncology and osteoporosis patient populations at risk for or diagnosed with ONJ.
effective_dosage: Not available

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on bone mineral density and bone formation in patients undergoing mandibular midline distraction osteogenesis.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT increased bone mineral density in the laser group compared to the control group, while the control group showed a higher rate of immature bone formation. These results suggest LLLT may enhance bone maturation and mineralization.
population_specificity: Nine patients aged 13-16 years with mandibular transverse deficiency (>5 mm).
effective_dosage: GaAlAs laser, 830 nm wavelength, 40 mW power, 8.4 J/cm² dose per spot, applied from 2 points on the mandibular midline in 8 sessions at 48-hour intervals.
study_duration: 8 treatment sessions (exact total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of using an 810 nm diode laser as an adjunct to modified Widman flap surgery versus modified Widman flap surgery alone in treating chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy significantly improved papillary bleeding index at 6 months and probing depth reduction at 9 months, with greater gains in clinical attachment levels at both 6 and 9 months compared to surgery alone. No significant differences were observed in plaque index scores between groups.
population_specificity: 25 patients aged 20-50 years with generalized chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: 4 J/cm² applied to the gingival surface after periodontal treatment.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 6 and 9 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single dose of helium-neon (He-Ne) low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could effectively reduce orthodontic pain caused by maxillary canine retraction.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain compared to the placebo side, with average pain scores of 2.35 ± 1.77 (laser) vs. 4.06 ± 2.85 (control). Statistical analyses confirmed the significant effects of both LLLT and time on pain reduction.
population_specificity: 16 male and 11 female orthodontic patients aged 12-21 requiring bilateral upper canine retraction.
effective_dosage: 632.8 nm, 10 mW, 6 J/cm² density (single dose).
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with pain assessments on days 1, 2, 4, and 7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of orthoses and patient education with and without Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in relieving symptoms of mild to moderate Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: Both groups (LLLT + orthoses and orthoses alone) showed significant reduction in BCTQ scores and symptom severity after six weeks, with no significant difference between groups. A higher proportion of participants in the LLLT group achieved minimal clinical change in symptom severity (92.3%) compared to the orthoses-only group (76.5%).
population_specificity: 48 patients (90% female, 10% male) with mild to moderate CTS, mostly women over 40 engaged in heavy hand duties, predominantly right-handed.
effective_dosage: 660 nm, 30 mW, continuous regime, beam area of 0.06 cm², fluency of 10 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding low-level laser therapy to standard physical therapy could delay the need for joint replacement surgery in elderly patients with bilateral symptomatic knee arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that patients receiving low-level laser therapy alongside standard physical therapy (protocol B) had significantly fewer joint replacement surgeries (1 out of 100 knees) compared to those receiving standard therapy alone (9 out of 100 knees) over a 6-year follow-up (p < 0.05). The results suggest that low-level laser therapy enhances the effectiveness of conservative treatment for knee arthritis.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with bilateral symptomatic tri-compartmental knee arthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) combined with aerobic and resistance training could improve cardiometabolic risk factors in obese women.
results_summary: LLLT combined with exercise significantly reduced neck and waist circumferences, fat percentage, visceral fat area, HOMA-IR, leptin, and ICAM-1 levels, with greater reductions in leptin and ICAM-1 compared to the placebo group. The results suggest LLLT enhances the benefits of exercise for cardiometabolic risk factors in obese women.
population_specificity: Obese women aged 20-40 years with BMI ≥ 30 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Infrared laser (808 nm, 100 mW, 50 J) applied for 16 minutes after each exercise session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and static stretching exercises, both alone and in combination, on pain, function, and mobility in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study design suggests potential efficacy of LLLT and stretching, but specific results are not provided in the abstract. The trial will evaluate pain, quality of life, function, mobility, knee range of motion, and hamstring shortening as outcomes.
population_specificity: 145 individuals aged 50-75 years with symptomatic-radiographic knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Gallium-Arsenide laser (904 nm, 40 milliwatts, 3 J/point, 27 J/knee) over 24 sessions for monotherapy and 9 sessions for combination groups, administered three times per week.
study_duration: 2 months for monotherapy and control groups, 3 months for combination groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing symptoms of burning mouth syndrome (BMS).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced BMS symptoms in all treatment groups, with sustained effects at follow-up. The IR1W and IR3W laser groups showed significantly better outcomes than the control group, and quality of life (OHIP-14 scores) improved across all groups.
population_specificity: 78 patients with burning mouth syndrome (BMS).
effective_dosage: IR1W (830 nm, 100 mW, 5 J, 176 J/cm², 50 s, weekly sessions, 10 sessions); IR3W (same parameters, three weekly sessions, 9 sessions); red laser (685 nm, 35 mW, 2 J, 72 J/cm², 58 s, three weekly sessions, 9 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the analgesic effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain caused by orthodontic separators.
results_summary: LLLT showed statistically significant pain reduction at 6h, 1d, 2d, and 3d after separator placement, but effects at 2h, 4d, and 5d were not statistically significant. The study concluded LLLT effectively reduces separator-induced pain, though high heterogeneity calls for better-designed RCTs.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment with separators.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Effects measured up to 5 days post-separator placement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining half-yearly hyaluronic acid injections with low-level laser therapy could delay the need for joint replacement surgery in elderly patients with bilateral symptomatic knee arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that only 1 out of 70 knees treated with hyaluronic acid and low-level laser therapy required joint replacement, compared to 15 out of 70 knees in the control group, indicating a significant reduction in treatment failure (P<0.05).
population_specificity: Elderly patients with bilateral symptomatic tricompartmental knee arthritis.
effective_dosage: Half-yearly hyaluronic acid injections and low-level laser therapy (specific laser dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Half-yearly interventions (exact study duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) versus pulsed electromagnetic field (PEMF) in treating hemarthrosis in children with hemophilia.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant improvement in pain, range of motion, ESR, and leucocyte levels compared to PEMF by 12 weeks, though no significant difference was found in knee circumference or the 6-minute walk test. Both therapies improved outcomes over time, with LLLT demonstrating superior efficacy for certain measures.
population_specificity: Thirty boys with hemophilia A, aged 9-13 years.
effective_dosage: Three treatment sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) to placebo LLLT in managing carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) and other wrist/hand soft tissue injuries.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy and placebo LLLT produced similar outcomes, suggesting no significant benefit of LLLT over placebo for the conditions studied.
population_specificity: Adults and/or children with soft tissue injuries and neuropathies of the wrist and hand, specifically carpal tunnel syndrome and de Quervain disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) compared to other treatments and control groups in managing pain and improving handgrip strength in patients with lateral epicondylitis (LE).
results_summary: The study found that treatment groups (including LLLT) showed clinically relevant pain relief and improved handgrip strength compared to control groups, though control groups still achieved 50-66% of the gains seen in treatment groups. Differences between treatments were smaller than differences between treatment and control groups.
population_specificity: Patients with lateral epicondylitis (LE).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Biolite, an ultra-low-level laser therapy device, on musculoskeletal pain and associated impairments, and its potential as a bridge between Western physiotherapy and acupuncture-derived protocols.
results_summary: The study suggests that specifically modulated laser light at low fluences can interact with human tissues, potentially inducing extracellular soft-tissue matrix reactions. It also indicates that peripheral acupuncture-like stimulation with the device may reduce motor control interferences, improving performance and reducing fall risk in elderly individuals.
