population_specificity: Individuals with musculoskeletal pain, including elderly individuals at risk of falls.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces pain in young patients undergoing orthodontic separation during the early mixed-dentition stage.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain perception on days 1 and 2 compared to the control group, with equivalent pain levels on days 3-5. The study concluded that LLLT is a viable analgesic option for young patients.
population_specificity: 40 children in early mixed dentition (mean age 8.05 years) requiring molar separation.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Laser application on the day of separation, with pain recorded over 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy in preventing oral mucositis in patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in overall oral mucositis incidence but showed a significant reduction in severe mucositis (17.65% in the laser group vs. 61.11% in the sham group) and less severe pain in the laser group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
effective_dosage: InGaAlP laser, 650 nm wavelength, 100 mW power, 2 J energy per point, 20 s per point, 70 J/cm² energy density.
study_duration: From the first day of conditioning until day +5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could effectively prevent recurrent Herpes Simplex Labialis (HSL) in immunocompetent individuals.
results_summary: The study found very limited data suggesting LLLT might be effective in preventing recurrent HSL, with only one to two RCTs supporting its efficacy. The evidence was insufficient to draw definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Immunocompetent individuals with recurrent Herpes Simplex Labialis (HSL).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) enhances the proliferation and viability of human adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly increased the proliferation of ADSCs in vitro (measured by absorbance) and in vivo (measured by cell count), with statistically significant results (p < 0.001). The enhanced ADSCs could have potential clinical applications.
population_specificity: Human adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) in vitro and rats in vivo.
effective_dosage: 830 nm Ga-Al-As laser (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on oral mucositis severity and quality of life in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) patients.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced the severity of chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis compared to the control group but did not improve oral or general health-related quality of life. Both groups showed deterioration in quality of life by day 7 post-HSCT.
population_specificity: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) patients undergoing high-dose chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: From the 1st day of the conditioning regimen until day 7 post-HSCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single application of Low-Level Laser Therapy (6J) could reduce pain perception caused by orthodontic elastomeric separators.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain perception among the laser, placebo, and control groups at any observed time point. Overall, pain perception varied widely but was generally mild.
population_specificity: 79 individuals aged 13-34 years at the onset of orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 6J (single application).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain and discomfort during orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in discomfort in the group receiving LLLT compared to the placebo group at all measured time intervals (5 minutes, 24 hours, and 120 hours after application).
population_specificity: 30 volunteers aged 18-40 years in need of orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 810 nm, 100 mW, 2J/cm² for 15 seconds per point.
study_duration: 5 days (separators in place), with follow-up assessments at 5 minutes, 24 hours, and 120 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential role of exercise training plus phototherapy (low-level laser therapy with light-emitting diode) in reducing chronic pain in women with fibromyalgia and temporomandibular dysfunction.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for low-level laser therapy alone, as it was part of a combination intervention (phototherapy plus exercise). The abstract indicates the trial will evaluate pain intensity, quality of life, and serotonin levels, but results are not yet provided.
population_specificity: Women aged ≥35 years with fibromyalgia and temporomandibular dysfunction.
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relevant indications of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in plastic surgery, focusing on its efficacy and safety for various conditions.
results_summary: LLLT improved flap survival in animals and chronic burn scars in humans, but was ineffective for venous ulcers and alopecia. No side effects were reported, though more comparative studies are needed.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (specifically for flap survival and wound healing studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on the quality of life (QoL) of patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) who developed oral mucositis.
results_summary: The study found that QoL improved over time in patients receiving LLLT for mucositis prevention, with the worst QoL scores observed shortly after transplantation (D+5/D+8) and better scores at later time points. The PROMS scale showed statistically significant differences in mucositis symptoms across the four evaluation times.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) who developed oral mucositis.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Evaluations occurred at multiple time points: (1) first day of treatment, (2) 5 days after autologous or 8 days after allogeneic transplantation, (3) once bone marrow had integrated, and (4) 30 days after discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the quality of facial scars 12 weeks after single low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and combined high-level laser therapy (HLLT) with LLLT in children.
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed statistically significant improvement in scar quality at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-therapy, with the combined HLLT+LLLT group demonstrating the most significant enhancement except for pigmentation and pliability. No improvement was observed in the untreated control group.
population_specificity: 41 children aged 1.5 to 5 years with facial scars after injury.
effective_dosage: LLLT (670 nm, fluence 3-5 J/cm²); HLLT (595 nm, fluence 9-11 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of postoperative Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on osseointegration and early success of self-tapping implants placed in low-density bone.
results_summary: LLLT improved implant stability significantly by the 5th postoperative week but had no significant effect on alkaline-phosphatase activity or early implant success rate, which was 100% in both groups. The study concluded that LLLT did not significantly enhance osseointegration in low-density bone.
population_specificity: 12 patients with self-tapping implants placed in the posterior maxilla (low-density bone).
effective_dosage: 6.26 J/cm² per implant, daily for 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for treating knee osteoarthritis (KOA) through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief or functional improvement between LLLT and sham laser therapy, both immediately after treatment and at a 12-week follow-up, based on VAS and WOMAC scores. The evidence did not support LLLT as an effective treatment for KOA.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (518 participants across nine RCTs).
effective_dosage: At least eight treatment sessions (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Therapy duration varied by study, with follow-up assessments up to 12 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an alternative treatment for recurrent aphthous ulcers (RAUs) by analyzing randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
results_summary: Both RCTs reviewed showed significant pain reduction and decreased healing times with LLLT, though varying irradiation conditions were used. The study suggests wavelength plays a key role in RAU treatment but does not recommend a specific protocol due to parameter differences.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent aphthous ulcers (RAUs).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varies by study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of diode low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for orthodontic pain control through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that diode LLLT significantly reduced orthodontic pain by 39% compared to placebo groups and lowered maximum pain intensity in parallel-design studies, though no significant effects were observed in split-mouth-design studies. However, methodological weaknesses and high risk of bias in most studies limited the strength of the evidence.
population_specificity: 659 participants from 11 countries undergoing orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on reducing the severity of oral mucositis (OM) and modulating salivary inflammatory mediators in head and neck cancer patients undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: LLLT reduced the severity of OM and was associated with decreased levels of specific inflammatory mediators (EGF, VEGF, IL-6, FGF) and a trend toward reduced levels of other cytokines and metalloproteinases, though some differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer receiving chemoradiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Three times per week (specific laser parameters not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: Up to 35 radiotherapy sessions (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of various treatments, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for shoulder impingement syndrome (SIS) using meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT was not recommended for SIS, as it was less effective compared to other treatments like exercise-based therapies and surgical interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with shoulder impingement syndrome (2300 participants across 33 randomized controlled trials).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical utility of low-level laser therapy for treating unilateral chronic plantar fasciitis in a placebo-controlled, randomized, double-blind study.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy significantly improved heel pain compared to placebo, with a mean visual analog scale score improvement of 29.6 ± 24.9 versus 5.4 ± 16.0 (p < .001). Doppler ultrasonography also showed reduced fascial thickness post-treatment.
population_specificity: 69 subjects with unilateral chronic plantar fasciitis.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 3 weeks (total of 6 treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the biologic mechanism of photobiomodulation (PBM) and summarize clinical findings on its applications in oral medicine, while identifying controversies and drawbacks.
results_summary: The study found PBM effective for conditions like oral mucositis, recurrent herpes simplex infection, and burning mouth syndrome, with no reported adverse effects. However, lack of standardized studies and ambiguity in laser parameters limit its credibility as a therapeutic modality.
population_specificity: Patients with oral medicine conditions (e.g., oral mucositis, herpes simplex infection, burning mouth syndrome).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on the in vitro proliferation of mesenchymal stem cells through a systematic literature review.
results_summary: The review found that most studies demonstrated an increase in the proliferation rate of irradiated stem cells, though protocols varied widely in wavelength, power density, and radiation time. The study concluded that LLLT positively influences stem cell proliferation but called for further experiments and standardized methodologies.
population_specificity: Mesenchymal stem cells derived from bone marrow, dental pulp, periodontal ligament, and adipose tissue.
effective_dosage: Varied protocols (wavelength, power density, radiation time, light polarization) – no single dosage specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Nd:YAG laser LLLT on pain, oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL), and swelling after sinus lift surgery.
results_summary: The study found that Nd:YAG LLLT significantly improved swelling and OHRQoL on the 3rd day post-surgery compared to the control group, but pain levels were similar between groups. No significant differences were observed by the 7th day.
population_specificity: Ten healthy patients requiring bilateral direct sinus lift surgery.
effective_dosage: 8 J/cm² energy density, 1064 nm wavelength, 0.5 W laser for 60 seconds immediately after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) in treating cellulite, with incidental mention of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) as a potential combination therapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on LLLT, only noting a lack of long-term follow-up data and details on combination therapies involving LLLT for cellulite.
population_specificity: 297 females with cellulite.
effective_dosage: Not specified for LLLT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis in elderly head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced the incidence and duration of severe oral mucositis, severe pain, and weight loss compared to the placebo group. No significant difference was found in enteral feeding use between the groups.
population_specificity: Elderly head and neck cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: 3.0 J/point at six anatomical sites bilaterally (12 locations), total dose/session=36 J, 5 sessions/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and compare the clinical outcomes and safety of non-invasive fat reduction techniques, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for localized subcutaneous adipose tissue reduction.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT, along with other non-invasive techniques, provided significant and satisfying fat reduction results without serious adverse effects. Results were consistent and reproducible, with circumferential reductions of 2 cm or more in areas like the abdomen, hips, and thighs.
population_specificity: 2937 patients (1114 treated with LLLT) undergoing non-invasive fat reduction procedures.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and Fascial Manipulation (FM) in treating Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: LLLT showed improvement in the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) at the end of treatment, but the improvement was not sustained at the three-month follow-up. FM demonstrated more consistent and lasting benefits in pain reduction and functional improvement.
population_specificity: 42 patients (70 hands with symptoms) clinically and electroneuromyographically diagnosed with CTS.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) with alvogyl for managing pain in patients with alveolar osteitis (AO) following mandibular third molar extraction.
results_summary: LLLT (red and infrared lasers) showed significant pain reduction compared to alvogyl at specific time points, with the red laser group outperforming others by day 3. The infrared laser reduced pain to acceptable levels but was not superior to other treatments.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with alveolar osteitis of mandibular third molars.
effective_dosage: 200 mW, 30 seconds per buccal/lingual surface and 30 seconds at the socket center (6 J per area), administered for 3 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an antimicrobial/antibiofilm technology and its impact on wound healing, focusing on studies without photodynamic agents.
results_summary: The study found beneficial effects of LLLT in promoting wound healing in both animal and human studies, but noted a lack of credible, reproducible studies and standardized procedures to fully assess its efficacy in biofilm eradication and wound healing.
population_specificity: Animal and human studies (chronic wounds and biofilm).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of laser acupuncture on pain and functional outcomes in musculoskeletal disorders and update existing evidence with recent RCT data.
results_summary: Two-thirds of the included RCTs reported positive effects, with moderate-quality evidence supporting laser acupuncture's effectiveness for musculoskeletal pain, particularly at long-term follow-up. Negative or inconclusive studies often lacked methodological quality or adequate dosage reporting.
population_specificity: Patients with musculoskeletal disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (but studies reporting positive effects commonly used appropriate treatment dosages).
study_duration: Long-term follow-up showed more consistent positive effects than immediate post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-dose laser therapy (5 mV, 650 nm) is effective in treating chronic cochlear tinnitus compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between the active laser treatment and placebo groups in reducing tinnitus severity, loudness, or frequency, concluding that the therapy was no better than placebo.
population_specificity: 66 patients with chronic cochlear tinnitus (33 in the laser group, 33 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 5 mV with a wavelength of 650 nm for 20 minutes a day, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in treating temporomandibular disorders (TMDs), specifically its impact on pain reduction and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT was not significantly better than placebo in reducing chronic TMD pain but significantly improved functional outcomes, including maximum active and passive vertical opening, protrusion excursion, and right lateral excursion.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) (454 patients across 14 RCTs).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy on pain, mandibular movements, and occlusal contacts in adolescents and young adults with temporomandibular disorder.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between the active and placebo laser treatment groups for pain, mandibular range of motion, or occlusal contact distribution. The preliminary results suggest a lack of response to low-level laser therapy in this population.
population_specificity: Adolescents and young adults aged 14 to 23 years with temporomandibular disorder.
effective_dosage: Wavelength of 780 nm, energy density of 33.5 J/cm², power of 50 mW, power density of 1.67 W/cm², and 20-second exposure time.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for treating shoulder tendinopathy, both as a monotherapy and in combination with physiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT provided significant and clinically important pain relief, both as a monotherapy and when combined with exercise therapy. Trials using inadequate laser doses were ineffective, while optimal doses showed statistically significant improvements in pain and function.
population_specificity: Patients with shoulder tendinopathy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (but adherence to World Association for Laser Therapy guidelines was noted).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing limb volume and pain in adults with breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
results_summary: The study found moderate-strength evidence supporting LLLT, with clinically relevant reductions in limb volume (75.7 ml within-group, 90.9 ml between-group) and pain (13.5 mm on VAS) immediately after treatment. Greater volume reductions were observed with LLLT compared to treatments without it, though between-group pain reduction was non-significant.
population_specificity: Adults with breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and laser-aided circumferential supracrestal fiberotomy (CSF) with conventional CSF in reducing relapse of corrected tooth rotations.
results_summary: LLLT showed a mean relapse percentage of 11.7%, comparable to conventional CSF (9.7%) and Er:YAG laser-aided CSF (12.7%), and significantly better than the control group (27.8%). Pain intensity was lower in LLLT compared to conventional CSF.
population_specificity: 24 patients at the finishing stage of orthodontic treatment with maxillary incisor rotations of 30° to 70° before therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (LLLT with "excessively high energy density" mentioned, but exact dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) enhances muscle hypertrophy and strength gains when applied before eccentric training in healthy subjects.
results_summary: LLLT combined with eccentric training resulted in significantly greater increases in muscle thickness and peak torque compared to training alone, with improvements of 15.4% vs. 9.4% in muscle thickness, 20.5% vs. 13.7% in isometric peak torque, and 32.2% vs. 20.0% in eccentric peak torque.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy male subjects.
effective_dosage: 810 nm wavelength, 200 mW power output, total dosage of 240 J per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of noninvasive and alternative therapies, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that Low-Level Laser Therapy has poor evidence or little to no literature support for efficacy in treating chronic low back pain. It was categorized among therapies with the weakest evidence base.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: Not available

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the literature to assess the role of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an experimental treatment for osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ).
results_summary: The abstract mentions LLLT as an experimental therapy for ONJ but does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes, suggesting it is still under investigation.
population_specificity: Patients with osteonecrosis of the jaw, particularly those associated with antiresorptive therapy (bisphosphonates or denosumab).
effective_dosage: Not available

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) as an alternative conservative treatment for ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow (UNE).
results_summary: LLLT showed significant improvements in clinical and electrophysiological parameters at the first month, comparable to ultrasound therapy, but only grip strength and latency improvements were sustained at the third month.
population_specificity: 32 patients diagnosed with UNE.
effective_dosage: 0.8 J/cm² with 905 nm wavelength, applied five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) could improve healing in the donor palatine area after connective tissue graft removal for gingival recession treatment.
results_summary: The test group receiving LLLT showed statistically significant smaller wounds at days 14 and 45 compared to the control group, though no significant differences were found in scar formation or tissue colorimetry. Patients reported mild to moderate discomfort with low analgesic use.
population_specificity: 32 patients with buccal gingival recession.
effective_dosage: Diode laser (AsGaAl, 660 nm) applied immediately after surgery and every other day for 7 days.
study_duration: 7 days of intervention, with follow-up assessments up to 90 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of connective tissue graft (CTG) alone versus CTG combined with low-level laser therapy (CTG + L) in treating gingival recession.
results_summary: The study found that CTG + L resulted in a higher percentage of complete root coverage (65%) compared to CTG alone (35%), though the mean root coverage percentages were similar (91.9% vs. 89.48%). Both groups showed significant reductions in dentine sensitivity and aesthetic improvements.
population_specificity: 40 patients with Miller Class I and II gingival recessions.
effective_dosage: Diode laser (660 nm) applied immediately after surgery and every other day for 7 days (total of 8 applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of non-pharmaceutical therapeutic modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, in facilitating the healing of chronic digital ulcers in patients with scleroderma.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Low-Level Laser Therapy, as it was one of several modalities reviewed, but none were proven most effective. Larger efficacy studies are needed for conclusive results.
population_specificity: Patients with scleroderma or systemic sclerosis (SSc) experiencing chronic digital ulcers.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of low-level laser therapy (specifically antimicrobial photodynamic therapy) on wound swelling, temperature changes, and oral health-related quality of life after surgical removal of impacted lower third molars.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy (aPDT) significantly reduced postoperative wound swelling and temperature on day 3 and improved oral health-related quality of life by day 7 compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Forty patients with impacted lower third molars (Pell-Gregory class IIB or IIC) requiring surgical removal.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of intravascular low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on growth factor levels and restenosis rates in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced FGF-2 levels and late lumen loss, with a lower restenosis rate (15.0%) compared to the control group (32.4%). No significant differences were observed in IGF-1 and VEGF levels, but TGF-β1 levels increased in the control group after 12 hours.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI).
effective_dosage: 808 nm LLLT (100 mW/cm², continuous wave laser, 9 J/cm², illuminated area 1.6-2.5 cm²).
study_duration: Intervention during PCI, with follow-up measurements at 6 and 12 hours, 1 month, and control angiography at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) combined with neuromuscular electrical stimulation on muscle architecture and functional capacity in elderly patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT alone did not significantly improve muscle thickness or pennation angle, nor did it enhance the effects of electrical stimulation. Functional capacity improved modestly across all groups, but no significant differences were observed between LLLT and other interventions.
population_specificity: Elderly females (66-75 years) with knee osteoarthritis (grades 2-4).
effective_dosage: Low-level laser therapy dose of 4-6 J per point, six points at the knee joint.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of electrotherapy modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for treating adhesive capsulitis, comparing them to placebo or other interventions.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant improvement in global treatment success compared to placebo at six days (80% vs. 10%) and, when combined with exercise, improved pain and function at four weeks and maintained functional benefits at four months. No adverse events were reported with LLLT.
population_specificity: Adults with adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.
study_duration: Six days for LLLT alone; eight weeks for LLLT plus exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in managing orthodontic pain by analyzing randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain scores and brought forward the most painful day compared to placebo, but evidence quality was very low due to methodological shortcomings and risk of bias. No statistically significant difference was found for the end of pain day.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment (tooth movement).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pulpal response in primary teeth, comparing it with traditional treatments like formocresol and calcium hydroxide.
results_summary: LLLT combined with calcium hydroxide showed the lowest degree of pulpal inflammation and satisfactory pulp tissue healing, while calcium hydroxide alone performed best in promoting hard tissue barrier formation and collagen density. Formocresol was associated with the highest incidence of internal resorption.
population_specificity: Twenty mandibular primary molars in children (exact age not specified).
effective_dosage: 660-nm wavelength, 10-mW power output, 2.5 J/cm² energy density for 10 seconds in continuous mode.
study_duration: Teeth were extracted at the regular exfoliation period (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of ultrasound (US) and low-level laser therapy (LLLT), with or without therapeutic exercises, on pain and grip strength in women with hand osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that the combined US + LLLT treatment significantly reduced pain sensitivity in women with hand osteoarthritis, with no significant improvement in grip strength. The placebo group showed no significant changes in pain sensitivity.
population_specificity: Women aged 60-80 years with hand osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Laser output power fixed at 100 mW (18 J per laser), 5 points irradiated per hand (3 min per point, 15 min per session), once weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prophylactic low-level laser therapy (LLLT) reduces the risk of severe mucositis compared to placebo or no therapy in cancer patients and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) recipients.
results_summary: Prophylactic LLLT significantly reduced the risk of severe mucositis, mean grade of mucositis, duration of severe mucositis, and incidence of severe pain compared to placebo or no therapy. The results were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Cancer patients and HSCT recipients.
effective_dosage: Not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pain reduction efficacy of Ga-Al-As diode laser (980 nm) therapy combined with exercise in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The Laser+EX group showed significantly greater pain reduction (Δ VAS 3.96) compared to the EX group (Δ VAS 2.23), with a statistically significant difference (p<0.001). The combination of laser therapy and exercise was effective for nonspecific chronic low back pain.
population_specificity: 100 patients with chronic low back pain (mean age 60 years).
effective_dosage: 980 nm diode laser, 20 W continuous wave, fluence 37.5 J/cm², total energy per point 1200 J, thrice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on serum TGF-β1 levels in patients with hypothyroidism caused by chronic autoimmune thyroiditis (CAT).
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant increase in TGF-β1 levels in the LLLT group compared to the placebo group, suggesting LLLT may influence cytokine response in CAT-induced hypothyroidism. No adverse effects were reported, but the mechanism remains unclear.
population_specificity: 43 patients with hypothyroidism due to chronic autoimmune thyroiditis, previously on levothyroxine therapy.
effective_dosage: 830 nm, 50 mW output power, 707 J/cm² fluence, administered in 10 sessions twice a week.
study_duration: 5 weeks (10 sessions over 2 sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in accelerating orthodontic tooth movement compared to other surgical and non-surgical approaches.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly increased the rate of canine retraction (WMD=0.42mm/month) over a period longer than 3 months, with moderate-quality evidence supporting its efficacy. However, the overall evidence was limited by the small number and heterogeneity of included studies.
population_specificity: Orthodontic patients (354 participants across 18 trials).
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.
study_duration: Longer than 3 months (specific duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether indirect exposure to 635 nm light could inhibit pro-inflammatory mediators in human gingival fibroblasts, similar to direct Low-Level Laser Therapy.
results_summary: Both direct and indirect 635 nm light exposure reduced COX-2 protein expression and PGE2 production in LPS-treated fibroblasts. Indirect exposure also decreased ROS levels and altered cytokine profiles, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects comparable to direct irradiation.
population_specificity: Immortalized human gingival fibroblasts (IGFs) treated with Porphyromonas gingivalis lipopolysaccharides (LPS).
effective_dosage: 635 nm wavelength (specific power/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether combining central rTMS and peripheral LLLT (including laser acupuncture) was more effective for tinnitus treatment than either method alone.
results_summary: The study found that combined rTMS and LLLT was effective in treating tinnitus, with effects lasting 4 weeks post-treatment, while LLLT alone showed no significant effect.
population_specificity: 30 patients with tinnitus, randomized into three equal groups.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on the severity of oral mucositis (OM) and inflammatory mediator levels in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) patients.
results_summary: LLLT reduced the severity of OM in HSCT patients and showed increased MMP-2 levels in saliva and higher IL-10 levels in blood plasma, but no significant differences were observed for other inflammatory mediators.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: From the first day of the conditioning regimen until day 7 post-HSCT (D + 7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-level laser therapy in treating pemphigus vulgaris and highlight the role of dentists in early diagnosis.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy showed immediate analgesia, improved wound healing, reduced discomfort, and no recurrence of lesions, but evidence remains insufficient for definitive recommendations.
population_specificity: Patients with pemphigus vulgaris, particularly those unresponsive to standard therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of incorporating phototherapy (low-level laser therapy and light-emitting diode therapy) into a therapeutic exercise program for individuals with osteoarthritis of the knee.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results as the study was proposed but not yet completed; data will be published after completion.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis of the knee.
effective_dosage: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: To assess whether adding low-level laser therapy to intravenous regional anesthesia improves pain management during and after surgical fixation of distal radius fractures.
results_summary: The laser-assisted group showed significantly lower pain scores, delayed need for fentanyl, reduced total fentanyl and pethidine use, and no differences in blood pressure or heart rate compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 48 patients undergoing surgical fixation of distal radius fractures.
effective_dosage: 808 nm laser at 4 J/point for 20 s over three cervical nerve roots (C5-C8) and 0.1 J/cm² for 5 min over the affected extremity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing complications (pain, trismus, and facial swelling) following impacted mandibular third molar extraction.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain on the first, second, and third postoperative days, decreased trismus by an average of 4.94 mm in the first three days, and reduced facial swelling with extraoral or combined intraoral/extraoral irradiation. However, efficacy conclusions were limited due to study heterogeneity and bias risks.
population_specificity: 193 participants undergoing impacted mandibular third molar extraction.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Effects assessed up to seven days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acute effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on physiological and electromyographic responses during cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) in healthy adults.
results_summary: LLLT significantly increased peak oxygen uptake (V'O2) and improved cardiovascular efficiency during CPET compared to placebo, but it did not significantly impact muscle fatigue as measured by electromyographic fatigue threshold (EMGth).
population_specificity: 18 untrained healthy adults (nine males, aged 22 ± 2 years).
effective_dosage: 20 s/site (850 nm, 100 mW/diode, 14 J/site).

study_goal: To determine the effects of low-level laser therapy on wound healing and identify optimal application methods in human and veterinary medicine.
results_summary: Doses of 3-6 J/cm² were found to be most effective, while doses above 10 J/cm² had deleterious effects. Wavelengths between 632.8 and 1000 nm yielded the best results in wound healing.
population_specificity: Human and veterinary medicine (not further specified).
effective_dosage: 3-6 J/cm² (effective range), above 10 J/cm² (deleterious).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combining Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with platelet-rich plasma (PRP) and autologous fat grafts for improving atrophic and contractile scars.
results_summary: Over 50% of patients reported excellent satisfaction with the combination treatment at 6 months, suggesting that LLLT combined with PRP and fat grafts may be effective for scar improvement. The study concluded that this combination is a promising therapeutic approach.
population_specificity: 64 patients with atrophic and contractile scars on various body parts (treated from 2008-2013).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combined phototherapy (using super-pulsed laser and red/infrared LEDs) on nonspecific knee pain compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that phototherapy significantly reduced pain from the 10th treatment onward and improved quality of life (SF-36® physical component) post-treatment and at follow-up compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 86 patients with nonspecific knee pain (VAS ≥ 30).
effective_dosage: 12 treatments with active phototherapy (905 nm super-pulsed laser, 875 nm and 640 nm LEDs).
study_duration: Treatment duration spanned 12 sessions, with follow-up assessments at 1 month post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the short-term efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain and improving nerve function in patients with mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study found significant pain reduction, decreased positive Tinel's sign occurrence, and improved median nerve conduction in the LLLT group compared to placebo, supporting its short-term efficacy for mild to moderate CTS.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome lasting less than one year.
effective_dosage: 780 nm GaAlAs diode laser (30 mW continuous wave, 0.785 cm², 38.2 mW/cm²), applied for 90 sec per point (2.7 J, 3.4 J/cm²/point), 20 total treatments (5x/week for 2 weeks, then 10 treatments every other day for 3 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on fibromyalgia symptoms compared to a placebo.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved fibromyalgia symptoms (FIQ, McGill Pain Questionnaire, VAS) compared to placebo, though tender point reduction occurred in both groups. The study suggests LLLT may be a useful therapeutic tool for fibromyalgia management.
population_specificity: 20 patients with fibromyalgia (10 in LLLT group, 10 in placebo group).
effective_dosage: GaAlAs laser (670 nm, 4 J/cm² on 18 tender points) three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if low-level laser therapy (LLLT) applied before resin composite placement reduces postoperative sensitivity in class V dental restorations.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced postoperative pain compared to placebo, with greater improvements in visual analogue scale (VAS) scores over follow-up periods (days 1, 14, and 30). Both groups showed pain reduction, but the laser group had superior outcomes.
population_specificity: 31 patients with 62 class V cavities (two teeth per participant).
effective_dosage: 630 nm, 28 mW, continuous wave, 60 s (1.68 J), applied once before restoration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) has an analgesic effect in patients with recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain (VAS rating decreased from 84.7 to 31.5) and improved the ability to eat, drink, and brush teeth compared to placebo (VAS decreased from 81.7 to 76.1). The results were statistically significant (P < .0001).
population_specificity: 40 patients with recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS).
effective_dosage: 6.3 J/cm² per treatment, administered on 3 occasions with a 1-day interval.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain and improving physical function in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in nocturnal pain, pain during walking and ascending steps, knee circumference, and improvements in joint mobility after LLLT treatment. The results suggest LLLT is effective for pain management in knee osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: 18 patients with knee osteoarthritis (initially 33 enrolled, but 15 excluded due to incomplete treatment).
effective_dosage: Two probes used—LO7 (810 nm, 50 mW, 6 J/cm²) and MLO1K (890 nm, 30 mW, 10 J/cm²)—administered three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of pre-exercise low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on quadriceps muscle performance in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a two-phase clinical trial to assess LLLT's impact on muscle performance (peak torque, total work, power, fatigue index) and biochemical markers of muscle damage, with results pending completion.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 4 Joules (Group A), 6 Joules (Group B), 8 Joules (Group C), and 0 Joules (placebo, Group D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could effectively reduce swelling and pain after orthognathic surgery.
results_summary: The study found no immediate postoperative differences in swelling or pain between irradiated and non-irradiated sides, but swelling significantly decreased on the irradiated side by days 3, 7, 15, and 30. Pain was less intense on the irradiated side at 24 hours and 3 days post-surgery, but neither side reported pain by day 7.
population_specificity: Ten healthy patients who underwent bilateral sagittal split with Le Fort I osteotomy.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Assessments were conducted up to 30 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of red and infrared laser therapy in treating temporomandibular disorders (TMD) and determine if one wavelength was superior.
results_summary: Both red and infrared lasers significantly improved TMD symptoms, with effects lasting up to 180 days. Infrared laser showed statistically better results at 180 days compared to red laser.
population_specificity: 19 subjects with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).
effective_dosage: 4 J/cm² in temporomandibular joints and 8 J/cm² in muscles, administered in three sessions.
study_duration: Treatment was administered over three sessions, with follow-up assessments at 24 hours, 30 days, 90 days, and 180 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) was effective for managing pain and improving mouth opening in patients with temporomandibular joint (TMJ) osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in mouth opening or pain reduction between the LLLT and placebo groups, though some within-group improvements in pain scores were noted for both groups. LLLT was not more effective than placebo for TMJ osteoarthritis under the tested parameters.
population_specificity: 20 patients with TMJ osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 810 nm laser (Peak power 80 W, average power 50 mW, 1500 Hz, 1 µs pulse width, 120 seconds, 6 J, 3.4 J/cm² per point), applied on four points around the TMJs and painful muscles three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces orthodontic treatment time by analyzing existing literature on its effects on tooth movement.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant changes in tooth movement in four out of five human studies and eight out of eleven animal studies, suggesting LLLT may reduce treatment time, though some studies showed no benefit.
population_specificity: Humans undergoing canine traction after premolar removal and rats undergoing first premolar traction.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varies by study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of 830 nm Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain relief and healing of closed bone fractures in the human wrist and hand.
results_summary: The laser group showed significant improvements in pain, functional disability, grip strength, and radiographic parameters compared to baseline and the placebo group, with results maintained at follow-up.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with closed bone fractures in the wrist or hand who did not undergo surgical treatment.
effective_dosage: 830 nm LLLT (average power 60 mW, peak power 8 W, 10 Hz, 600 sec, 9.7 J/cm² per fracture site) administered five times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the functional improvement of lower limbs in patients with periostitis using Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) compared to a placebo.
results_summary: Patients receiving LLLT showed significant pain improvement by day 2 or 5, though no significant difference was found between baseline and post-treatment pain scales. LLLT positively affected proprioception, with notable improvements in postural stability and limits of stability during dynamic testing.
population_specificity: Adults with sports-related lower leg pain and confirmed periostitis via bone scans.
effective_dosage: 1.4 J/cm², three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of low-level laser therapy on post-exercise musculoskeletal recovery and identify the optimal dose and application parameters.
results_summary: The study design suggests a systematic approach to testing different laser doses and powers, but specific results are not provided in the abstract. The intention is to determine parameters that reduce muscle fatigue, injuries, and accelerate recovery.
population_specificity: 28 high-performance athletes
effective_dosage: Phase 1: 2 J, 6 J, 10 J, 0 J (placebo); Phase 2: 100 mW, 200 mW, 400 mW, 0 mW (placebo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for accelerating tooth movement during orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT could accelerate orthodontic tooth movement within 7 days and 2 months, with lower energy densities (5 and 8 J/cm²) appearing more effective than higher ones (20 and 25 J/cm²).
population_specificity: 211 patients from six countries undergoing orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: 5, 8, 20, and 25 J/cm² (specific frequency not mentioned).
study_duration: Intervention effects measured at 7 days and 2 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy on neurosensory impairment recovery in patients who underwent sagittal ramus split osteotomy, compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy significantly improved neurosensory recovery, with 62.5% of participants regaining initial two-point discrimination and 87.5% recovering directional discrimination at 6 months. The laser group showed 68.75% improvement in general sensitivity VAS compared to 21.43% in the placebo group (p=0.0095).
population_specificity: Patients with neurosensory impairment following sagittal ramus split osteotomy (n=31, laser group=17, placebo=14).
effective_dosage: Laser applications on days 1, 2, 3, 5, 10, 14, 21, and 28 post-surgery (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and occlusal splints in reducing myofascial pain in patients with temporomandibular disorders.
results_summary: Both LLLT and occlusal splint therapy significantly reduced pain scores compared to placebo, with no significant difference in efficacy between the two treatments. LLLT was found to be as effective as occlusal splints for pain relief.
population_specificity: 30 patients diagnosed with myofascial pain according to the Research Diagnostic Criteria for Temporomandibular Disorders (RDC/TDM).
effective_dosage: 1,064 nm, 8 j/cm², 250 mW, once daily for 10 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) on pain relief and functional improvement in patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The study found that both HILT and LLLT combined with exercise significantly reduced pain (VAS) and improved knee function (WOMAC) after 6 weeks, with HILT being more effective than LLLT. Both treatments outperformed exercise alone.
population_specificity: 53 male patients with knee osteoarthritis, mean age 54.6 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of connective tissue mobilization (CTM) on quality of life and emotional status in healthy subjects.
results_summary: CTM significantly improved lateral trunk flexion to the right and emotional status, with notable differences in general health and emotional role limitations. Some SF-36 subscales initially favored the control group, but no differences remained post-intervention.
population_specificity: 100 healthy student volunteers (aged 19-21 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of physical relaxation (e.g., massage) compared to no intervention or alternative interventions in reducing stress among healthcare workers.
results_summary: Massage was more effective than no intervention in reducing stress at one-month and one-to-six-month follow-ups, but no considerable difference was found between massage and taking extra breaks.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers suffering from occupational stress.
effective_dosage: Not specified
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from less than one month to more than six months.
